title: Catalyst
description:
Ever since I started at Dashboard we were asked to put third party chat systems onto our clients websites. In my opinon the majority of them looked and functioned like garbage and I always wanted to build a better version. After going to NADA (the biggest dealer confrence in North america), I set off to start building some call tracking software built on the Octane framework. This didn't last long and I pivoted to building a full blown chat app with a little twist. Instead of being stuck to having to be on the computer to see and respond to visitors on your site, You were able to forward the message to your phone via SMS and MMS messages. I used the Twilio api to forward messages to the dealer or the user if they simply put in their cell number.

I used NodeJS and Socket.io to provide the realtime chat and the Twilio NodeJS module to interact with Twilio. There were a few hardships along the way and one of the biggest ones was to build the criteria on when or if to forward the message. There was a couple of iteractions on this but I ended up coming up with something elegant that solved for forwarding and made everything easier to read.

I teamed up with a collegue to help with the interface and design of the admin area and the chat that appears on a dealers site. Everything ended up looking super crisp and it was very easy to use. We built it into the Octane platform to provide a seamless integration to the other product on the Octane platform. While this never went to production it was a great side project build from scratch by myself and build the presentation and design with a collegue.

title: Odometer
description:
Odometer is the big data component of the Octane platform. It is a simple script that you embed on a site and it will collect clickstream data for each user that visits their site.

Before starting on this I had only done a little work with MongoDB with very few entries. Odometer has millions of entries and I needed to run large queries with analysis. I ended up using the built in Mongo functions MapReduce and Aggegation to run the quieres and analysis in one task and save the aggregated data separtly so I can query it for the front end later on. I learned a lot how the internals on Mongo and its indexes work which sped up the queries in a very noticiable way.

title: Revups
description:
This was one of the funnest and interesting projects with the most gotchas and challenges that I have ever worked on. The dealer would have access to an admin area to build and completely customize a page takeover on their site. After embedding a javascript snippet on their site, they have full control the pages the takeover shows up on, how ofter and when it shows up

Since there are over 30 different modules I wanted to build a framework to build the modules as quick as possible and for each one to follow the same convention so everything is consistent. The idea was that all of the boilerplate would be done in the framework and you would just need to build the specific functionality and styles for each specific module. I accomplished this by building an event and object based solution that was easy to build new modules and track the events within the module.

title: Convert With Octane
description:
The grand vision of Octane was to become an app store for auto dealerships. The meant that the code needed to be flexible and allow to easily add and remove features both in core services and the site itself.

Building Octane and the Octane framework was the biggest learning experience I have encountered in my career to date. Learning new design patterns, how to scale both with users and products, and learning Angular were among the largest challenges. Angular plays a huge role in the interface. We needed a way to share components across multiple products (Spark, Glovebox V3, Revups) but also have those products be used in isolation. What we came up with was a build process that would build files based on smaller files that had only one piece of logic in them. This gave us tha ability to override specific directives, functions, or views throughout the suite of products.

title: Walmart BlackWeb
description:
I was really excited when I landed this project. The best way for me to learn something is by actually doing it but most of the time i get bored and go onto something else before finishing it off. Fortunatly working for a client, not finishing is not an option, so I had to learn how to build a native android app fast.

The app was part of an installation promoting walmarts black web speakers. A person would get into a booth and click an icon corresponding to where a sound played out of the speaker played. There were two rounds, one with speakers in the 4 corners of the booth playing tunes and the second playing through bluetoother headphones out of each ear.

The real issue with the project where there was 4 speakers (one in each corner of the room). Initially I had 4 single channel bluetooth speakers and would randomize the connection to each speaker. The problem was that once a speaker connects through bluetooth, a connect sound would play from the speaker. After wasting days on tring to figure out how to turn this sound off I needed another idea. I ended up using two 2 channel speakers, connecting one through the headphone jack and the other through bluetooth. Since each speaker had a left and right channel I was able to mimic the sound coming out of all four corners of the room, success! (or so I thought)

While everything worked well the first and sometimes the second time through, there was a bug that was difficult to recreate that had to do with the bluetooth speaker not connecting properly. After 50 hours of search google and stackoverflow I finally figured out the issue has to do with the newer version of the Android MediaPlayer library. Once switching back to V4 everything worked fine and it was a feeling that I will never forget. (Check out this stackoverflow question for a full explanation.)

title: Villaggio
description:
This was my first experience in using Drupal to build a site with. It was a straight forward build but Drupal definetly slowed me down (which afterwards I wasn't that big of a fan Drupal as a whole).

It was a one page site to show off recipes that use the Villaggio bread. Since the map needed to be clicks and hovered on an SVG was used. This worked well in most browsers but there were some work arounds that needed to be worked out for older borwsers and Safari.

title: Choose Nissan
description:
Choose Nissan was a site done for Nissan Canada to feature their monthly specials. Nissan, like every other car company, has monthly specials split up into different regions. The west coast might have specials on trucks while Quebec might have specials on compacts. The user is automatically is directed to their region from a landing page where they must enter their postal code. Along with 5 different regions, one is in both English and French (can you guess what region that would be?)

It was relatively easy to accomplish with the responsiveness using foundation and there wasn't much custom javascript to do, besides the dealer locator. The site is built on Glovebox so most of the backend was already available, I just had to write a little bit of php to get custom info from the database. On top of the html and php there are a few tools written in python to populate certain content on the site.

title: Fletchers
description:
The Fletchers site was for their brand launch in Canada. It was a relatively simple site to show off their products, create some tasty recipes and create BBQ tips for their BBQ leagues.

The site was built with foundation and built on Glovebox, and because of that it was a nice quick build with little problems. A difficulty I did encounter was in angled text in the big daddy, which I wanted used the `rotate` css property so it would be able to be editable through Glovebox. In the end I found a happy medium between font size and position.

title: The Orange Difference
description:
The Orange Difference was built for ING Direct Canada to create an online version of their public accountability pdf document. This site had to be built in html so it could be ported to different servers easily. The static site mixed with the amount of content casued it to be a long tedious build. On top of all that it also had to be in English and French.

Due to the uniqueness of the site, I could not use any frameworks so I really had to flex my brain muscles on how to achieve the transition effects, loading the content and switching from desktop to mobile. There were many hurdles in this site with some of the biggest ones being, the sheer amount of content, the blind transition effect, and the graceful transition to mobile.

title: You Move Me
description:
This site was for the launch of the new brand You Move Me, located in both the US and Canada. This site had a lot of firsts for me which included, the first non automotive site built on Glovebox; the first site on Glovebox that needed a blog engine; the first time I used had used foundation css framework; and the first time I had coded (a somewhat) responsive layout. With their business model, the need for franchises to have their own site within the corporate site was needed to be built into Glovebox.

Since there were many new things with this site, there were many challenges with this site. I had to build a blog engine into Glovebox, which mainly included creating a taxonomy schema and all the hooks for that into Glovebox. When it comes to the layout, the sidebar was the most difficult part of the front end. In the end I had to use some javascript to manipulate the layout on document load (something that I cringe at the thought of but sometimes there’s no other way).

title: Glovebox v2 Themes
description:
This is the second version of the themes that are used for dealers on the Glovebox system. In this second version of the themes the css framework and how everything is structured was changed. With encorporating Foundation it gave us the responsivness we wanted and with the custom sass hiearchy I built, it gave us the ease of extending themes.

These were the first responsive dealer sites on any system in Canada and it was no easy task. The hardest part to this build was definetly the navigation. I wanted to use the built in Foundation navigation but the html structure was very limiting when creating the drop downs on the full sized site. With a lot of perseverance, patients and a little magic I found a solid solution and now it functions as was intended.

title: Chatplode
description:
Chatplode was a business venture that the client wanted to create to allow a user to upload an image and chat about it for up to 24 hours. The concept was very simple, and I had to do a little design work since a Theme Forest theme was provided. The difficult part was creating a production site built with nodejs and MongoDB

This was my first site that went into production that was built on NodeJS + MongoDB. On top of having to figure out how to push a nodejs live on a rackspace server (which I also setup for the client), I ended up writing my own chat application code from scratch. Yes I know there are a lot of frameworks available for this but it is something I always wanted to write, for some reason. Unfortunately the client has since taken the site down.

title: Windsor Chamber of Commerce
description:
The Windsor Chamber of Commerce site was for a group that represents various business in and around the Windsor, Ontario area. It was built on wordpress and also integrated Membee profiles and directories.

The most difficult part of this site BY FAR was integrating the Membee member info. It is a very old looking (and functioning) directory/login utility that was extremely hard to use and just achieve simple pulls of information. Other than that it was a very standard wordpress build with using custom post types and multiple plug-ins to end up with a very sleek and speedy site experience.

title: sc2Lounge
description:
SC2Lounge was the first personal site I have made and launched (beside personal profile sites). When watching Starcraft 2 and e-sports videos on YouTube I often got very aggravated when the first out of a series would end and the next video would not automatically start. SC2Lounge was my solution, and after over a year of coding it and re coding it and recoding it, it launchedd.

I rewrote all of the code on this site 3 times before I was happy with how the code was written and how the site functioned. The most noticeable improvement were the benchmarks in updating process of the database. I started off using php to load the user data from YouTube and zend lucene to build the search index. The performance was fine for the first time around, however, once that virgin cloud lifted I started looking for another alternative. After doing a lot of research I decided that using java and apache lucene was the best bet. The only problem was that I didn’t know java. I took the time to learn the language, which was a lot like Actionscript 3, and after writing the script that did the same thing php was doing, I couldn't have been happier with the results. There were amazing performance improvements when building of the search index. I actually got it working on the first try and I had to watch the directories to make sure it was working properly due to the speed. In indexing 20,000 database entries, php took ~5 minutes while java took ~9 seconds. No brainer right!

title: Glovebox v1 Themes
description:
These were the themes on the Glovebox system when it launched. When the first site launch on Glovebox in 2011, the web was just starting to really adopt the new standards in html5 and especially css3. Because of this, all of these sites had images for everything that is now done with css.

This was the largest project I have ever taken on. This was not only a standard front-end site build, it was also creating the backend hooks and then hooking everything together. These sites are 100% compatible down to IE7 (which we all know is super fun). I had to also build a few jQuery plugins, as well as incorporate several more.

title: The Grid TO
description: The Grid was a relaunch of the free magazine `Eye Weekly` in Toronto. This was, and still is, the largest site that I have ever worked on, in respect to the amount of views, amount of content and . The site was built on wordpress with buddypress integration for user profiles.

title: Rocscience
description: Rocscience is a software company that provides rock for engineers and educational purposes. This site has several products and a ton of content ranging from software info, news and events and product info. The site is compatible down to IE6, to the point where it looks almost identical to modern browsers. There are over 30 different templates on the site and it was my first project that I lead the front end development. This still looks and functions great and has really withstood the test of time.

title: Extra Money Giveaway
description: The Extra Money Giveaway was a mircosite developed for H&R Block as a fun way to give away money and free tax services. This site hasn't been up for a while now but it was one of my first full site builds I had ever done. The site was built using flash and papaervision 3d in order to achieve the 3d floating. The most intertesting part that was done on this site was the reflection on the cubes. Papervision has a reflection class for the cubes but it did’t achieve the look that we were going for so I had to write my own. In the end I duplicated the image that was on the face of the cube on the fly, flipped it and created a gradient mask on the bottom from the bottom up.

title: Filtrete 3D
description: Filtrete was a site created for 3M to show off the efficiency furnace filters. This site was one of my first site I worked on at Dashboard and the amount I learnt on it was unbelievable. The coolest part of the site, was an awesome stereoscopic 3d adventure down a furnace grate to see all the creepy crawlers that exist. Another cool part to the site was the individual filter pages where different specs of `dust` would fly in from all angles and get stuck on the filters. This site won an FWA Site of the Day award, Applied Arts award and was featured in the stereoscopic edition of .Net Magazine.
